results.title: Lies [Widescreen] (E)
results.creator_credit: Jang Sun-Woo, Chul Shin, Korea Pictures and Shincine Communications
results.brief_description: Jang Sun-Woo’s Lies (based on a notorious Korean novel, whose author Jang Jung Il was sentenced to six months jail over its content) takes the very simple premise of a sexual affair between an older man and a younger woman and turns it on its head. Right from its opening scenes where the ‘actors’ discuss their roles and the difficulties of performing on-screen sex, the audience is led into deep analysis of what film authenticity means. This becomes a tantalizing proposition as the affair between J (Lee Sang Hyun), 38-year-old married man and the innocent Y (Kim Tae Yeon), an 18-year-old student determined to lose her virginity, becomes a sadomasochistic one. As these two people explore just how far the other is willing to go, we as an audience are asking the same question of the film as each erotic act becomes seemingly more real. Sun-Woo heightens this by adopting a documentary verite style that distances itself from its main protagonists. Finally the blurred boundaries between what is performance and what isn’t ultimately begs the question, ‘does the camera lie?’. In Korean with English subtitles.

results.title: Lickety-split licorice
results.creator_credit: Jan Steen, Joe Hayward, Moreland-Latchford Productions and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: A boy and girl making liquorice, stretch it outside in a tangled web which leads to utter chaos as people become entangled in it. When someone snips the gigantic piece of liquorice, the scenes flash rapidly backwards to reality. No spoken commentary - English intertitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jan Steen, Joe Hayward, Moreland-Latchford Productions and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: Licensed to drive (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Jeff regains his licence after losing it for drink-driving. He is determined to keep it this time and has to find ways of sticking to the zero limit. Eventually he is able to meet the challenge of going to a party and enjoying himself without alcohol. He can keep to his decision : “When I drink I don’t drive and when I drive I just don’t drink”.

results.title: Library organization
results.brief_description: Explains the card cataloguing system and the Dewey decimal system in use in one typical library and shows how more detailed understanding of library organisation speeds up work in the library and makes for better studying and better use of study time.
results.description: Explains the card cataloguing system and the Dewey decimal system in use in one typical library and shows how more detailed understanding of library organisation speeds up work in the library and makes for better studying and better use of study time.

results.title: Library on wheels
results.creator_credit: Bill MacDonald, Gudrun Parker and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Behind the library van, making its three-weekly 750-mile circuit of British Columbia’s beautiful Fraser Valley, lies the story of twenty-one communities pooling their resources to solve the problems of bringing books to the people in scattered isolated farming areas. The library van is greeted at every stop by eager borrowers - farmers, fishermen, lumbermen, engineers, adults and children alike. Books are important to all the people of Canada, and the people of the Fraser Valley have made sure that the books they want are readily available to meet their needs. Librarians for the vans are trained at the University of Toronto at the McGill University, Canada.

results.title: Libraries are kids stuff (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Alex Hankocy and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: At Myers elementary school library in Tucson, Arizona, the librarian, teachers and students help each other use every bit of library space as a resource centre for perceiving, reading, experiencing and learning beyond the classroom. The film presents the idea that the traditional concept of primary school libraries is outdated. The library depicted is a modern resource centre in which children also have access to nonbook materials. Suitable for middle and upper primary and teacher/tertiary levels.

results.title: Liberation: May 8 9AM 1945
results.creator_credit: Arnold Schwartzman, Marvin Hier, Moriah Films and Simon Wiesenthal Centre
results.brief_description: This video explores the Allied campaign to liberate Europe and Hitler’s genocidal war against the Jews. It combines film footage, music, radio broadcasts and interviews. It uses 1942, (a time when Hitler was still at the heights of his power) as a starting point, and ends at V-E Day. Narrated by Ben Kinglsey, Miriam Margolyes, Patrick Stewart, Jean Boht and Whoopi Goldberg.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arnold Schwartzman, Marvin Hier, Moriah Films and Simon Wiesenthal Centre

results.title: Liberace: behind the music
results.creator_credit: David Greene, Murray Shostak, Entcorp Communications and Syzygy
results.brief_description: The glitz, the glamour, the bright lights, the man known as “Mr Showmanship”, Liberace, entertained and fascinated audiences for several decades in theatres and nightclubs right across America. His artistry and brilliance as a piano virtuoso and his over-the-top eccentricities in fashion combined with a saucy “camp” sense of humour made Liberace famous the world over, but with that fame also came notoriety, innuendo and questions as to Liberace’s sexuality, his close relationship to his mother and his relationships with young men. “Liberace: behind the music” was the unofficial and unauthorised television biopic based on the recollections of Liberace’s business manager and as such explores his life, family and relationships with somewhat more depth and accuracy (warts and all) than the “official” family-oriented “Liberace” (starring Andrew Robinson) which was telecast one week earlier in October 1988. Victor Garber stars as Liberace, with Maureen Stapleton as his mother Frances Liberace. Cast also includes Saul Rubinek, Michael Dolan, Michael Wikes. This appears to be a reasonable portrayal of the very private Walter Valentino Liberace who eventually died on 4 February 1987 of pneumonia caused by AIDS.
